entry.title: My experiences
entry.content:
Introduction​

Malta & Italy​

First of all, in 2021, one of my classmates and I have decided to discover Malta and Italy for one month.
We chose Italy because many friends recommended us the destination, especially for it's landscapes and it's cultural richness.
Italy was a dream, who doesn't dream of discovering Italy ?

Read more

Portugal​

Then, in 2022, I set myself the challenge of traveling alone for 2 weeks. It was my first time ! I went to Portugal for several reasons :

  • It's close to France (if something had happened, I could have come back to France quickly)
  • I didn't knew much about Portugese culture and habits
  • I wanted to discover its architectural richness

Read more

Greece​

Finally, in 2023, I decided to conquer Greece. I enjoyed traveling alone, so I have started the adventure all over again, but this time for 3 weeks.
I chose Greece on the recommendation of friends, as well as people I met on my previous trips. They recommended it to me because the Greek islands are very safe places to travel alone.

Read more

entry.title: Greece
entry.summary: I decided to do this trip alone, but this time by going away for 3 weeks with a slightly more organized trip.
entry.content:
I decided to do this trip alone, but this time by going away for 3 weeks with a slightly more organized trip.

My journey :

  • Athens: 5 days

  • Naxos: 5 days

  • Paros: 6 days

  • Milos: 5 days

  • Athens: 2 days

My inter-island transportation was all made by boat. This trip had marked me, it was very different from the ones I've done before because it was full of discoveries.
I was moving around a lot, so I didn't get much rest, but that was the beauty of this trip. Every day there was something new to discover.

Athens​

In Athens, I took an Airbnb that was a bit out of the center, but I had the metro line right next to the apartment. I made this choice in order to save money on accommodation.
The neighborhood was really nice, with a supermarket right next door and very typical little cafes nearby.

I was also very happy not to be in the city center, because Athens is a very touristic city. It's always noisy and I wouldn't have been able to get a good night's sleep.


Athens is THE city to do, everything is incredible, the streets, the atmosphere and especially the number of historical sites to visit !
Every day, I took the metro from my small apartment to the center and then did everything on foot. It was very tiring but it allowed me to see as much of the city as possible.

The fact that I did everything on foot meant that I got lost in some streets, and even though I had my phone with me, I preferred to try to wander around and find my way on my own.
It also meant that I could talk to locals or tourists to find my way back, and most importantly, ask for advice on what to visit in the area.

I had the chance to visit Athens in early june, prices were reasonable because there weren't many tourists.
But, when I came back at the end of june, prices were very excessive. In some places, such as souvenir stores, the prices had almost doubled !

tip

  • When you eat or have a drink, the waitress will always bring you a glass of water and refill it when you run out. It's a gesture that I think shows how much the Greeks care about others.

  • Do not hesitate to go outside the center, for example from Kallithea where I was (metro: 10 minutes from the center). The area may not seem the best at first glance, but you'll be safe and have everything you need close by !

  • If you want to visit monuments such as the Acropolis, or any of the other historical monuments, if you're under 25 and a citizen of the European Union, you can visit these monuments free of charge with proof of identity (identity card or passport).

Naxos​

This island is simply gorgeous; it's a little Mykonos, only better. Despite the fact that there is more and more tourism, it has not yet reached the level of Mykonos.
As a result, this splendid blue-and-white island is still very affordable and, above all, much more pleasant to walk around and enjoy the Greek atmosphere.

I ate the best ice cream of my life at the "Waffle House".

I slept in a hostel run by a local man, Alexandros, offering really affordable rooms just a 3-minute walk from the beach. It was a little out of the center, but an easy 20-minute walk along the beach.

Alexandros gave me great advice, and thanks to him I was able to get a great deal on a scooter from Scooter Mania and visit the right places, as Naxos is the largest island in the Cyclades.
Thanks to him, I was able to swim in the magnificent beaches on the west side of the island and not waste my time with too many trips to the center of the island.

caution

Be careful when you rent a scooter to check with the company if you have to return it with a full tank or not. I was tricked, I put a full tank in my scooter because when I picked it up it was almost empty and I didn't even use a quarter of it, but the company didn't reimburse me for the overfill...



Paros​

The atmosphere is completely different, everything is much greener and drier. It is mostly very mountainous.

I stayed in a guesthouse and I really didn't regret it! My hosts were very welcoming. I was able to talk to them at length about their lives, mine, and all sorts of other things.
It was very enriching to be able to have such conversations and, above all, it allowed me to greatly improve my spoken English!

I only rented a scooter in the city center for 2 days because I wanted to fully explore the island. Then I took the bus to continue my tour because there was a bus stop close to my room. 2 days to visit the whole island was not enough, I recommend to do it in 3 days to have time and not be in a hurry.

I don't really recommend the north-east of the island, which is beautiful but very touristic, with lots of restaurants with large terraces that "spoil" the landscape.

On the 4th day, I got an alert on my phone that there was a big risk of a storm, which was very impressive because my phone started to ring by itself.
So my hosts offered to take me to a supermarket to stock up on supplies in case we couldn't get out. It just goes to show how nice the Greeks are.
Rest assured, in the end the storm didn't affect us too much and I was able to continue my visits.

info

Take good walking shoes and a large hat, as there is little shade and the climate is quite dry.



Milos​

Milos, oh great Milos.

This island is just gorgeous ! I have never seen such a small place with so many landscapes! Everything was majestic!
I've never felt better than on this island, everything is beautiful, it's on a human scale so it's very pleasant to walk around.

I rented a scooter from the first day until the end of my stay, because I really wanted to take my time and make the most of this last week of my trip.

Milos is a "mountain" island with lots of hairpin bends, and unfortunately I paid the price. On the first day, while trying to get to the island's big supermarket, I slipped on an oil puddle and fell.
Fortunately, it was nothing serious, just a burn on my knee and shoulder.
But the fall made me realize just how kind and good the Greeks are.
Immediately after I picked up the scooter, a car stopped and gave me water and towels to clean myself up.
A few minutes later, a young man came up to me with a bottle of water because he had seen me fall and had gone to get me some so I could come to my senses and get cleaned up.

I couldn't even count the number of cars, scooters and quads that stopped to ask me how I was and if I needed anything.

tip
  • Take a powerful quad bike and be very, very careful on the roads 😉
  • You must go to O! Hamos! Tavern. It is an authentic family-owned Greek tavern.


caution

Be sure to check your travel dates, as on even days Blue Star Ferries goes to Milos, while on odd days only SeaJets operates. Remember that Blue Star Ferries boats cost at least 4 times less than SeaJets boats.

Learnings​

  • Being alone and far away
  • Learn more about Greek mythology

entry.title: Portugal
entry.summary: I decided to travel alone. I had the opportunity to discover 2 beautiful cities :
entry.content:
I decided to travel alone. I had the opportunity to discover 2 beautiful cities :

  • Lisbon (capital city of Portugal) for 5 days
  • Porto for 10 days

If I had to do it all over again, I'd spend a little more time in Lisbon, because there's so much to see. I didn't have time to go to Sintra (a beautiful town near Lisbon).

Lisbon​

Lisbon is a city that makes you want to explore, to discover what might be in every neighborhood, on every street. It’s a safe and friendly city, relatively small but with so much to see. It is the ideal place to spend a few days.

Lisbon is a very hilly city, I've covered most of it on foot ! Luckily I have good legs and good shoes.

Lisbon is full of nooks and crannies, little streets with hidden stores or cafes with loudly laughing people inviting you in for a drink. I wish I'd spent more time in Lisbon, it is a city where you can easily feel at home.

tip

You must go to Pasteis de Belem and eat their Pastel de nata ! (they are the best in Portugal)


Porto​

It is the same country, but with such different landscapes.
Just between the west and north of Porto, the landscapes are very different. More industrial landscapes with old buildings in the north, while in the west there is much more green, life, shops, etc....
The atmosphere in Porto was very different from the one in Lisbon. Porto is alive day and night and there are more young people in Porto than in Lisbon.

During my breaks in bars or cafes after my long walks, I had the opportunity to chat with locals. This helped me improve my English, even though not all the Portuguese I met spoke English.
Thanks to them, I was able to go to places to eat and visit that I'd never have thought of !

Being alone in the same city for 10 days was very pleasant, but long. I would not recommend spending that much time alone in the same city because there were times when I didn't know what to do.
But on the positive side, it really allowed me to take the time to do nothing, enjoy every moment and be more aware of everything around me.



tip

You can do everything on foot or by using the old tramway or buses. You will only need to rent a car or scooter only if you are planning to move out of the city. It is a city with excellent transportation links.

Learnings​

  • Being alone in another country
  • Discovering Portuguese traditions and history
  • Fighting my shyness

entry.title: Malta & Italy
entry.summary: My trip was split into 2 parts. I started with 1 week in Malta and then 3 weeks in Italy.
entry.content:
My trip was split into 2 parts. I started with 1 week in Malta and then 3 weeks in Italy.

Malta​

I was very surprised by the beauty of Malta's landscapes.
I'd researched places to go before, but seeing them with my own eyes was even more amazing.

I really enjoyed this part of the trip because we were in a big house with many other foreigners (Turkish, Colombian, German,...). And we had the opportunity to talk, eat and drink with them.

The tourists were mainly teenagers from all over the world. We met a lot of young people who came to work for the summer season. They were usually handing out flyers for organized parties, visits, activities,...

We had to live in a community, there were rules in the house so that everyone behaved well. It was interesting to see how people managed to do with the rules.

Malta is not an expensive destination, but during the summer season and especially in the big cities (Paceville, Valetta,...) prices are the same as in France.

There is a real contrast in social wealth across the island. In fact, it is not uncommon to see magnificent buildings surrounded by dilapidated ones.

Advices​

You must see Blue Grotto (sea caves). The water and light reflections are beautiful and worth seeing !

tip

If you want to have a wonderful experience, go to Blue Grotto early in the morning.

Italy​

During my trip in Italy I had the opportunity to explore Bari, Rome, Florence, Pisa,...

Bari​

I do not recommend this city for a long stay, there is not much things to do and discover. Especially because there are not many historic monuments and places to visit. I think it is a good destination for 2 or 3 days maximum.

Compared to Malta, Bari is very affordable, a bottle of Peronni (Italian beer) costs 1€, pizza's were sold at 6€ and cocktails 7€.

We had the chance to be there during the final of the 2021 European footbal tournament. Italy won against England and the city went crazy, Italians were celebrating everywhere in the streets.

Here is a picture that reflects the atmosphere of this night:


What to do ?​

  • You can go to Polignano a Mare, it's a little balnear station 30 minutes away. To get there you have to take the regional train (tickets cost about 5€).
  • Visit the historical center, there are many typical small streets
  • Go to the Piazza Mercantile, it is a place with a lot of restaurants, bistros, cafes, animations,...
  • Explore the 13th-century Norman-Swabian castle of Bari

Rome​

I highly recommend visiting Rome, I think 7 days is perfect to visit the city and all it's monuments and places.

Rome is a city full of museums, squares, Roman buildings and other must-sees. I strongly advise you equip yourself with good walking shoes. The city is so large and interesting that long distances can be covered quickly...

What you must do ?​

  • Visit the Pantheon, the Colosseum, the Circus Maximus, Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum
  • The Vatican and the Sistine Chapel
  • Enjoy traditional pasta with a glass of wine at Pasta e Vino Osteria. It is someone we met during our trip who recommended the address to us. It is considered as the best place to taste real Italian pastas with the typical Italian atmosphere.
  • Visit the Trastevere neighborhood. The area is one of the oldest and most authentic neighborhoods in Rome and is definitely the place to be in Rome for nightlife.
  • If you have time you can go to Castel Gandolf. It is commonly known as the Pope's City, as it houses the Pope's summer residence. There is a train that can take you there.

Florence​

Our host was a Greek living in Italy. He gave us a lot of advice and took us to places where only locals go.

He cooked us pasta with pesto, offered us Chianti wine (regional wine). He even taught us how to make an excellent espresso with a Moka Pot.

He talked about his daily life and his life in Greece (which planted a seed in my mind). We shared many things together, how we see the life, our cultural habits, how important it is for us to travel and open ourselves to the world.

Vasselyo takes us to see his friends, then we ate street food. There were many people selling their goods (drinks, food,...). It is a common thing in Italy to pay something to drink and sit somewhere in public and discuss.

What to do ?​

  • Cathedral of Santa Maria del Fiore
  • Piazzale Michelangelo at the sunset / at night. It offers a panoramic view of Florence.
  • Ponte Vecchio, it is the oldest bridge in Florence. It is known for the many shops on and around the bridge, which used to be the domain of blacksmiths, tanners and butchers. But they were replaced by jewelers and goldsmiths.
tip

If you want to spend a fantastic evening, you need to sip a cocktail at View on Art Rooftop Cocktail Bar. It is a rooftop restaurant with a stunning view of the Duomo and great music.


Pisa​

Pisa was the last stop on our trip. We only spent one day there and it was enough for us. I suggest to stay there for 2 days because there are not many things to do and see.

  • See and visit the Tower of Pisa and the Duomo di Pisa
  • See the Chiesa di Santa Maria della Spina (a gothic church located on the bank of the Arno river)
  • Borgo Stretto, the shopping street of Pisa

Learnings​

  • Talked and shared moments with international people
  • Had the opportunity to practice my spoken English
  • Italians live in the evening and lately
  • They are dangerous drivers (they always exceed the speed limits, stop and traffic lights are not respected)
